4  the Challenged Provisions attempt to implement those priorities in ways that are inconsistent with 
5  the Constitution and existing statutes.  Defendants thus do not suffer harm from being unable to 
6  enforce those unlawful provisions.  And any potential “chill” on agency action is speculative at 
7  this stage and does not outweigh the strong public interest in upholding the rule of law and 
8  Plaintiffs’ constitutional rights.  See Washington, 2025 WL 509617, at *14; see also PFLAG II, 
9  2025 WL 510050, at *23.

iD tc 15    Separately, the Court rejects Defendants’ request that the Court “clarify that it does not 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  prohibit the President from reissuing a different directive or Executive Order and does not limit 
S d nr
ee 17  the defendant agencies from taking actions pursuant to their legal authority to regulate in 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  furtherance of the substantive policy priorities in the Executive Orders,” ECF No. 61 at 48, 
19  because those questions are not properly before the Court.   
20  VIII.  BOND  
21  Rule 65(c) provides that the Court “may issue a preliminary injunction or a temporary 
22  restraining order only if the movant gives security in an amount that the court considers proper to 
23  pay the costs and damages sustained by any party found to have been wrongfully enjoined or 
24  restrained.”  Fed. R. Civ. P 65(c).  But “[d]espite the seemingly mandatory language, ‘Rule 65(c) 
25 
 
26 
13 Defendants DOJ; Attorney General Pamela Bondi; DOL; Acting Labor Secretary Vince 
Micone; OFCCP; Acting OFCCP Director Michael Schloss; OMB; OMB Director Russell 
27 
Vought; HHS; HHS Secretary Robert K. Kennedy, Jr.; HUD; HUD Secretary Scott Turner; 
NARA; Deputy Archivist William J. Bosanko; NEH; and NEH Chair Shelly C. Lowe. 
28 
 
50 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 81     Filed 06/09/25     Page 51 of 52
 
1  invests the district court ‘with discretion as to the amount of security required, if any.’”  
2  Johnson v. Couturier, 572 F.3d 1067, 1086 (9th Cir. 2009) (quoting Jorgensen v. Cassiday, 320 
3  F.3d 906, 919 (9th Cir. 2003)) (emphasis in original).  The District Court thus “may dispense with 
4  the filing of a bond when it concludes there is no realistic likelihood of harm to the defendant from 
5  enjoining his or her conduct.” Id. (quoting Jorgensen, 320 F.3d at 919).  Here, because the Court 
6  finds Plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits of their claims as to the three enjoined provisions, 
7  the Court does not find that a preliminary injunction is likely to pose any harm to Defendants by 
8  preventing them from enforcing those unlawful provisions.  Furthermore, waiving bond is 
9  particularly appropriate here where Plaintiffs are nonprofit organizations suing in large part 
10  because they are suffering monetary harm from the unlawful provisions of the Challenged Orders 
11  that have withheld federal funding critical to their everyday operations.  See Miller v. Carlson, 768 
12  F. Supp. 1331, 1340 (N.D. Cal. 1991) (explaining that courts have waived bond to avoid denying 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  access to judicial review). 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  The Court therefore orders Plaintiffs to post a nominal bond in the amount of $1,000.00.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  See Barahona-Gomez v. Reno, 167 F.3d 1228, 1237 (9th Cir. 1999), supplemented, 236 F.3d 1115 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  (9th Cir. 2001).   
S d nr
ee 17  IX.  REQUEST FOR STAY 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Defendants request that the Court stay its preliminary injunction pending the disposition of 
19  any appeal filed, or in the alternative, administratively stay the injunction “for a period of seven 
20  days to allow the United States to seek an emergency, expedited stay from the court of appeals if 
21  an appeal is authorized.”  See ECF No. 61 at 48–49. 
22  As a threshold matter, Defendants’ request is procedurally improper. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 
23  7(b)(1) (“A request for a court order must be made by motion.”).  But regardless, as the Court has 
24  found that Plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the merits relating to the three enjoined provisions, 
25  the Court denies Defendants’ request for a stay.  See Manrique v. Kolc, 65 F.4th 1037, 1040 (9th 
26  Cir. 2023) (providing that one of the primary factors considered for whether a stay should be 
27  issued is whether the applicant for the stay has “made a strong showing that he is likely to succeed 
28  on the merits” (quoting Nken v. Holder, 556 U.S. 418, 434 (2009))); see also Washington v. 
51 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 81     Filed 06/09/25     Page 52 of 52
 
1  Trump, No. 25-807, 2025 WL 553485, at *3 (9th Cir. Feb. 19, 2025).  Moreover, Defendants have 
2  not carried their burden of showing that they are likely to face “irreparable injury . . . during the 
3  period before the appeal is decided.”  See Doe #1 v. Trump, 957 F.3d 1050, 1058–59 (9th Cir. 
4  2020). 
5    Similarly, the Court denies Defendants’ request for an administrative stay.  The purpose of 
6  an administrative stay is to “preserve the status quo until the substantive motion for a stay pending 
7  appeal can be considered on the merits.”  See Nat’l Urban League v. Ross, 977 F.3d 698, 700–01 
8  (9th Cir. 2020).  Because the Court has found that a preliminary injunction is necessary precisely 
9  to alter the status quo and address the irreparable harm that Plaintiffs face absent an injunction, an 
10  administrative stay is not appropriate here.   
11  CONCLUSION 
12    The Court grants, in part, Plaintiffs’ motion for a  preliminary injunction consistent with 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  the discussion in this Order.  The Court will enter a separate preliminary injunction order.

SUPPLEMENTAL DECLARATION OF JOE HOLLENDONER IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS’ 
COMPLAINT AND MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, CASE NO. 4:25-cv-01824-JST 
 
 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 57     Filed 04/07/25     Page 2 of 8
 
 
1 I, Joe Hollendoner, hereby state as follows: 
2 1.  I am the Chief Executive Officer of the Los Angeles LGBT Center (“LA LGBT 
3 Center”), a nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization based in Los Angeles, California, that provides a 
4 variety of services to members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (“LGBTQ”) 
5 communities. I have served in this capacity since 2022. I joined the staff of the LA LGBT Center 
6 in 2021. 
7 2.  On February 25, 2025, I executed a Declaration (ECF No. 47-5) in support of 
8 Plaintiffs’ Complaint and Motion for a Preliminary Injunction, filed on March 3, 2025 (ECF No. 
9 47) to prevent Defendant agencies and their leadership from enforcing Executive Order No. 14168 
10 “Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the 
11 Federal Government” (“Gender Order”), issued January 20, 2025; Executive Order No. 14151 
12 “Ending Radical and Wasteful DEI Programs and Preferencing” (“DEI-1 Order”), issued January 
13 20, 2025; and Executive Order No. 14173 “Ending Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit-
14 Based Opportunity” (“DEI-2 Order”), issued January 21, 2025 (collectively, the “Executive 
15 Orders”), and related agency directives.  
16 3.  Since executing that Declaration on February 25, 2025, I learned that Defendant 
17 National Institutes of Health (“NIH”) has terminated a federal grant awarded to the University of 
18 California, Los Angeles (“UCLA”) under which the LA LGBT Center is a subawardee. I also 
19 learned that LA LGBT Center has been advised by an Federal agency employee that it must remove 
20 certain  words  or  acronyms,  including  “LGBT,”  “queer,”  “transgender,”  etc.  from  any  new 
21 materials created in connection with our Intimate Partner Violence Training Program or the 
22 funding received for that program, pursuant to a $1.5 million grant from the Office of Family 
23 Violence and Prevention Services (“OFVPS”), is likely to be terminated.  
24 4.  I am submitting this supplemental declaration to inform the Court of these recent 
25 developments and the negative impacts they have had and will continue to have on LA LGBT 
26 Center and the people that it serves.  
27
2 
28
SUPPLEMENTAL DECLARATION OF JOE HOLLENDONER IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS’ 
COMPLAINT AND MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, CASE NO. 4:25-cv-01824-JST 
 
 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 57     Filed 04/07/25     Page 3 of 8
 
 
1 A.  NIH Grant Terminations 
2 Race & Place Grant 
3 5.  Upon information and belief, on or about September 5, 2024, UCLA won a grant 
4 from NIH (the “NIH Grant”) to study the intersection of race and substance use and HIV outcomes 
5 in Los Angeles County under the project title: “Race & Place: The Impacts of Racial Inequality on 
6 Substance Use and HIV Outcomes in Los Angeles” (the “Race & Place Study”). The NIH Grant 
7 was for the period September 15, 2024 through July 31, 2029.  
8 6.  The Notice of Award for the NIH Grant is attached as Exhibit A.  
9 7.  Based on findings in prior related studies, the population of substance using men 
10 who have sex with men (“MSM”) of color who are living with HIV are among the most 
11 marginalized, underserved, and stigmatized members of the LGBTQ community. As a result, these 
12 individuals suffer from high rates of homeliness, food insecurity, unemployment, lack of access to 
13 medical and mental health care, and lack of access to substance us recovery services, among other 
14 basic needs. The Race & Place Study, therefore, is intended to identify and address factors 
15 contributing to racial inequities in HIV care. Through comprehensive research and analysis, the 
16 study seeks to develop and implement improved healthcare delivery models aimed at enhancing 
17 racial equity and reducing disparities in HIV treatment and outcomes. The findings from this study 
18 are intended to inform public health strategies and policies, ultimately contributing to more 
19 equitable healthcare systems and improved health outcomes for racially diverse populations 
20 affected by HIV.  
21 8.  On  January  31,  2025,  LA  LGBT  Center  was  awarded  a  Cost  Reimbursable 
22 Subaward by UCLA under the NIH Grant pursuant to which LA LGBT Center is performing all 
23 phases of study implementation for the Race & Place Study. The subgrant to the LA LGBT Center 
24 totaled $2,068,560. 
25 9.  The Cost Reimbursement Research Subaward Agreement between UCLA and LA 
26 LGBT Center is attached as Exhibit B.  
27
3 
28
SUPPLEMENTAL DECLARATION OF JOE HOLLENDONER IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS’ 
COMPLAINT AND MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, CASE NO. 4:25-cv-01824-JST 
 
 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 57     Filed 04/07/25     Page 4 of 8
 
 
1 10.  LA LGBT Center’s work on the Race & Place Study includes recruiting, enrolling, 
2 and  maintaining  the  optimal  study  cohort,  conducting  study  visits,  coordinating  retention, 
3 performing  data  collection  and  entry,  providing  data  reports,  responding  to  queries,  and 
4 maintaining participant files.  
5 11.  LA  LGBT  Center  also  employs  peer  navigators  and  case  managers  that  are 
6 responsible for meeting with study participants and addressing their social, medical, and mental 
7 health needs. LA LGBT Center also employs research coordinators and laboratory technicians who 
8 oversee phlebotomy, collection and processing of specimens. 
9 12.  At least two of LA LGBT Center’s employees dedicated to the Race & Place Study 
10 are fully funded by the NIH Grant.  
11 13.  LA  LGBT  Center’s  work  in  the  Race  &  Place  Study  is  consistent  with  the 
12 requirements of 42 U.S.C. § 283p, which directs that the Director of NIH “shall, as appropriate, 
13 encourage  efforts  to  improve  research  related  to  the  health  of  sexual  and  gender  minority 
14 populations, including by—(1) facilitating increased participation of sexual and gender minority 
15 populations in clinical research supported by the National Institutes of Health [and] (2) facilitating 
16 the development of valid and reliable methods for research relevant to sexual and gender minority 
17 populations[.]” 
18 14.  Upon information and belief, on or about March 20, 2025, UCLA received a Notice 
19 of Termination, purporting to immediately terminate the NIH Grant (the “Termination Notice”).  
20 15.  According to the Termination Notice, the NIH Grant was terminated because 
21 “[r]esearch  programs  based  primarily  on  artificial  and  non-scientific  categories,  including 
22 amorphous equity objectives, are antithetical to the scientific inquiry, do nothing to expand our 
23 knowledge of living systems, provide low returns on investment, and ultimately do not enhance 
24 health, lengthen life, or reduce illness.”   
25 16.  The Termination Notice further justified the NIH Grant’s termination by claiming 
26 that “so-called diversity, equity, and inclusion (‘DEI’) studies are often used to support unlawful 
27
4 
28
SUPPLEMENTAL DECLARATION OF JOE HOLLENDONER IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS’ 
COMPLAINT AND MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, CASE NO. 4:25-cv-01824-JST 
 
 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 57     Filed 04/07/25     Page 5 of 8
 
 
1 discrimination on the basis of race and other protected characteristics, which harms the health of 
2 Americans.” 
3 17.  The Termination Notice is attached as Exhibit C.  
4 18.  This termination is devastating to the LA LGBT Center and the communities that 
5 were to be served by the Race & Place Study. Without access to this essential funding stream, the 
6 Race & Place Study simply cannot continue and will cease to exist. As a result, participants in the 
7 study will go without many of the important services they receive for participating including, 
8 critically, substance use and HIV treatment.  
9 19.  Additionally, without the funding from the NIH Grant, the LA LGBT Center will 
10 be forced to terminate the two employees dedicated to the Race & Place Study and whose positions 
11 are entirely funded by the NIH Grant.  
12 Gender-Affirming Stigma Intervention to Improve Substance Misuse and HIV Risk among 
13 Transgender Women Grant 
14 20.  Upon information and belief, the Illinois Institute of Technology in July 2024 won 
15 an NIH Grant (“Gender NIH Grant”) to investigate health disparities and outcomes among 
16 transgender and gender-diverse populations, focusing on substance use, mental health, and barriers 
17 to healthcare access to inform evidence-based interventions and improve public health strategies. 
18 21.  On August 1, 2024 the LA LGBT Center was awarded a subaward under this grant 
19 in the amount of $12,536. 
20 22.   A copy of the subaward letter is attached as Exhibit D. 
21 23.  The LA LGBT Center uses these funds to partially fund at least one employee to 
22 conduct recruitment and enrollment of participants into this clinical trial. 
23 24.  On March 21, 2025 the grant was terminated based on “Research programs based 
24 on gender identity are often unscientific, have little identifiable return on investment, and do 
25 nothing to enhance the health of many Americans. Many such studies ignore, rather than seriously 
26 examine, biological realities. It is the policy of NIH not to prioritize these research programs.”  
27
5 
28
SUPPLEMENTAL DECLARATION OF JOE HOLLENDONER IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS’ 
COMPLAINT AND MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, CASE NO. 4:25-cv-01824-JST 
 
 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 57     Filed 04/07/25     Page 6 of 8
 
 
1 25.  The Termination Notice is attached as Exhibit E. 
2 26.  The termination letter indicates that no corrective action was deemed possible due 
3 to the fundamental incompatibility of the grant's premise with current NIH priorities, directly 
4 aligned with the implementation of the contested Executive Order. 
5 27.  The NIH Grants are not the only federal funding that the LA LGBT Center relies 
6 upon and experiencing the termination of the NIH Grant has only heightened the concerns and 
7 challenges we are already facing because of the Executive Orders that were detailed in my 
8 February 25 Declaration. And now, enforcement of the Executive Orders against us is not only 
9 imminent but is clearly already occurring and I am concerned that the NIH Grant is just the first 
10 of many existing federal grants LA LGBT Center receives funding under that will be terminated. 
11 B. The Domestic Violence National Resource Center Grant.  
12 28.  LA LGBT Center also receives a $2.25 million grant (the “DV Resource Center 
13 Grant”) from the OFVPS, a component of Defendant U.S. Department of Health & Human 
14 Services, to serve as a national resource center focused on domestic violence related to the 
15 LGBTQ+ community. As part of that training and technical assistance program, the LA LGBT 
16 Center is required to submit all training materials for approval before they go into the field.  
17 29.  A purpose of the OFVPS is to award grants to create and maintain national and 
18 special issue resource centers focused on preventing and addressing family, domestic, and dating 
19 violence. These centers provide resource information, training, and technical assistance to enhance 
20 the capacity of individuals, organizations, governmental entities, and communities in delivering 
21 effective intervention services. 42 USC §10410(a)(2). 
22 30.  In addition to these, the statute authorizes grants to “support training and technical 
23 assistance that address emerging issues related to family violence, domestic violence, or dating 
24 violence, to entities demonstrating related expertise.” 42 USC §10410(a)(2)(B)(ii). The LA LGBT 
25 Center was funded to be such a national resource center for LGBTQ+ related domestic violence 
26 issues. 
27
6 
28
SUPPLEMENTAL DECLARATION OF JOE HOLLENDONER IN SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS’ 
COMPLAINT AND MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, CASE NO. 4:25-cv-01824-JST 
 
 

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 57     Filed 04/07/25     Page 7 of 8
 
 
1 31.  Recently, the LA LGBT Center was advised that it must remove terms like “LGBT,” 
2 “queer,” “trans,” “transgender,” etc. from materials submitted to the agency or else it risks having 
3 the DV Resource Center Grant terminated.   
4 32.  Loss of the DV Resource Center Grant would mean that LA LGBT Center would 
5 no longer be able to provide its intimate partner violence training and those living in abusive 
6 relationships would suffer as a result. LA LGBT Center, therefore, is put in an impossible position. 
7 Do we continue to do what we have always done and what is central to our mission and recognize 
8 the existence of members of the LGBTQ community, including transgender individuals, or do we 
9 recast our work to combat financial harm to our organization and prevent the elimination of certain 
10 programs? Even if we wanted to do the latter (we do not), it is not possible: “LGBT,” one of the 
11 prohibited terms, is in our very name.

COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
 

Case 3:25-cv-01824     Document 1     Filed 02/20/25     Page 3 of 73
 
 
1 1.  Plaintiffs are mission-driven nonprofits that specialize in the delivery of high-
2 quality healthcare, social, and other critical services to members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, 
3 transgender, and queer (“LGBTQ”) community; an organization dedicated to ending the human 
4 immunodeficiency virus (“HIV”) and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (“AIDS”) epidemic; 
5 and a historical society whose mission is to record and celebrate the history of the LGBTQ 
6 community. All Plaintiffs receive federal funding to support their work. 
7 2.  Plaintiffs  bring  this  suit  for  declaratory  and  injunctive  relief  with  respect  to 
8 Executive Order No. 14168, 90 Fed. Reg. 8650 (Jan. 20, 2025), “Defending Women From Gender 
9 Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government” (“Gender 
10 Order”), issued January 20, 2025; Executive Order No. 14151, 90 Fed. Reg. 8339 (Jan. 20, 2025), 
11 “Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing” (“DEI-1 Order”), 
12 issued January 20, 2025; Executive Order No. 14173, 90 Fed. Reg. 8633 (Jan. 21, 2025), “Ending 
13 Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit-Based Opportunity” (“DEI-2 Order”), issued January 
14 21, 2025 (collectively, the “Executive Orders”); and related agency directives that seek to enforce 
15 illegal, ultra vires Presidential action. 
16 INTRODUCTION 
17 3.  In the days following his inauguration, President Donald J. Trump issued a flurry 
18 of executive orders plunging the federal government into chaos. Included in those orders were 
19 three that seek to punish and defund Plaintiffs for acknowledging the existence of transgender 
20 people, advocating for their rights, and adopting an equitable approach to the provision of their 
21 services that recognizes the rich diversity of the United States.  
22 4.  The Gender Order in particular expresses and imposes on others a disparaging, 
23 demeaning,  idiosyncratic,  and  unscientific  viewpoint  about  transgender  people  and  gender 
24 identity; repudiates the existence of transgender people; deems their identities to be “false;” and 
25 orders their exclusion from government recognition and protection in numerous aspects of their 
26 lives.  
27
28
  1

19 personhood, and by tailoring services in a manner that acknowledges and addresses the many

8 i.  Plaintiff SFAF 
9 44.  Plaintiff  SFAF  provides  HIV  prevention  and  treatment  to  clients  living  with 
10 HIV/AIDS or who are at risk of contracting HIV. SFAF receives federal grants and/or contracts 
11 and is dedicated to ending the HIV epidemic.  
12 45.  As an essential part of its work, SFAF confronts and combats HIV-related health 
13 disparities among gay and bisexual men, transgender women, cisgender women, Black people, 
14 Latinx people, and, in particular, people residing at the intersections of these identities. The federal 
15 grants that SFAF receives and the statutory schemes that authorize such grants command such an 
16 approach.  
17 ii.  GLBT Historical Society 
18 46.  Plaintiff GLBT Historical Society is devoted to recording and disseminating the 
19 stories of LGBTQ people and their struggle for legal recognition and respect across generations.  
20 47.  The GLBT Historical Society exists to tell these stories. The history of LGBTQ 
21 people is one of self-expression, pride, and a celebration of the very existence of all LGBTQ 
22 people. The GLBT Historical Society’s Archives and Special Collections are among the largest 
23 and most extensive holdings in the world of materials about LGBTQ+ people, occupying more 
24 than 4,000 linear feet of storage and spanning more than a century’s worth of LGBTQ+ history.  
25 48.  To advance its mission, the GLBT Historical Society receives and has received 
26 federal grant funding from Defendant NARA and Defendant NEH.

2 Rescissions  Order”),  which  rescinded  several  Biden  Administration  Executive  Orders  that 
3 provided protections for transgender people.1  
4 62.  President Trump then issued Executive Order 14183 (“the Military Service Ban 
5 Order”), banning transgender people from serving in the military, and revoked Executive Order 
6 14004, which had allowed all qualified persons to serve in the military.2  As justification, President 
7 Trump declared that “expressing a false ‘gender identity’ divergent from an individual’s sex cannot 
8 satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service” and “is not consistent with the 
9 humility and selflessness required of a service member.” The language in Executive Order 14183, 
10 on its face, expressly and unequivocally evidences discriminatory animus toward transgender 
11 people. 
12 63.  President Trump also issued Executive Order 14187 (“Denial of Care Order”), 
13 declaring that “it is the policy of the United States that it will not fund, sponsor, promote, assist, 
14 or support the so-called ‘transition’ of a child from one sex to another,” and directing the 
15 immediate  defunding  of  medical  institutions  that  provide  gender-affirming  medical  care  to 
16 transgender people under the age of nineteen.  
17 64.  President Trump has acted to discriminate against transgender people in other 
18 contexts as well. For example, Executive Order 14170 forbids government employers from 
19 considering or even recognizing gender identity in the hiring process,3 and Executive Order 14190 
20 eliminates federal funding for K-12 schools that “directly or indirectly support” the “instruction, 
21 advancement, or promotion” of “gender ideology” in their curricula for students or in training

24 speech activities are permitted and which are prohibited, creating a broad chilling effect and

26 funding, including Plaintiffs.

25 implement it both facially and as applied to them. 
26 305.  Plaintiffs’ cause of action arises from the principle of non-statutory review to enjoin 
27 Executive Officers and Departments seeking to enforce illegal, ultra vires Presidential action.  
28
  67   
COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 

Case 3:25-cv-01824     Document 1     Filed 02/20/25     Page 70 of 73
 
 
1 306.  The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees that no person 
2 shall be “deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law.”  
3 307.  The Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause makes the Fourteenth Amendment’s 
4 guarantee of equal protection applicable to the federal government, its agencies, its officials, and 
5 its employees.  
6 308.  The Gender Order discriminates against Plaintiffs based on sex and transgender 
7 status by depriving them of funding because they serve and advocate for an end to discrimination 
8 against transgender people.  
9 309.  The Gender Order also discriminates based on sex and transgender status against 
10 the transgender people whom Plaintiffs serve. Plaintiffs assert claims on their own behalf and also 
11 on behalf of the people they serve, including patients, clients, and the patrons who visit the GLBT 
12 Historical Society to learn about their community’s past. These patients, clients and patrons face 
13 barriers to asserting their own claims and protecting their own interests.  
14 A.  The Gender Order is Motivated by Animus.  
15 310.  The Gender Order expressly discriminates based on transgender status on its face 
16 by  expressing  a  disparaging,  demeaning,  idiosyncratic,  and  unscientific  viewpoint  about 
17 transgender people; repudiating the very existence of people who are transgender, deeming them 
18 “false”; and ordering their exclusion from government recognition and protection in every aspect 
19 of their daily lives, from identification documents to healthcare, housing, and employment, among 
20 other elements.  
21 311.  The Gender Order was issued for the openly discriminatory purpose of expressing 
22 governmental disapproval of transgender people and rendering them unequal to others. It is a 
23 status-based classification of persons undertaken for its own sake, something the Constitution’s 
24 Equal Protection Clause does not permit. 
25 312.  Thus, the Gender Order imposes a broad and undifferentiated disability on a single 
26 named group: transgender people. Its sheer breadth is so discontinuous with the reasons offered 
27 for it that the Gender Order is inexplicable by anything but animus toward the class it affects.  
28
  68   
COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 

Case 3:25-cv-01824     Document 1     Filed 02/20/25     Page 71 of 73
 
 
1 313.  This animus-laden purpose is not a legitimate governmental interest and fails under 
2 any standard of review.  
3 314.  Laws that target and discriminate against a class of people for the sole purpose of 
4 making them unequal violate equal protection.  
5 B.  The Gender Order Discriminates Based on Sex and Transgender Status.  
6 315.  The Gender Order facially creates a classification based on transgender status by 
7 repudiating  the  existence  of  transgender  people,  deeming  them  “false,”  and  ordering  their 
8 exclusion from government recognition and protection in numerous aspects of their lives. 
9 316.  The Gender Order also facially creates a classification based on sex because it 
10 creates idiosyncratic and unscientific sex-based definitions for the purpose of exclusion and directs 
11 agencies to withhold grants from entities that “promote gender ideology.” 
12 317.  Discrimination  on  the  basis  of  sex  and  transgender  status  is  presumptively 
13 unconstitutional and subject to heightened scrutiny.  
14 318.  The Gender Order lacks even a rational or legitimate justification, let alone the 
15 exceedingly persuasive or compelling one that is constitutionally required.  
16 319.  The Gender Order also lacks adequate tailoring under any standard of review. 
17 320.  The Trump Administration has been clear that its goal is to erase the transgender 
18 community from participation in society—an effort that results in the literal denial of equal 
19 protection and causes ongoing harm to the Plaintiffs and the people that they serve.  
20 321.  Plaintiffs are entitled to a declaration that the Gender Order violates the equal 
21 protection component of the Fifth Amendment.  
22 322.  Plaintiffs are further entitled to a preliminary and permanent injunction preventing 
23 the Agency Defendants from enforcing or implementing the Gender Order.  
24
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
25
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs seek judgment against the Defendants for: 
26
a.  A declaratory judgment under 28 U.S.C. § 2201(a) that the Executive Orders and 
27
their implementing agency actions are unlawful and unconstitutional; 
28
  69   
COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 

Case 3:25-cv-01824     Document 1     Filed 02/20/25     Page 72 of 73
 
 
1 b.  Preliminary  and  permanent  injunctions  enjoining  Agency  Defendants  from 
2 implementing and enforcing the Executive Orders; 
3 c.  Costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees as permitted by law; and 
4 d.  Such further relief as the Court may deem just and equitable.  
5 Dated this 20th of February, 2025.      Respectfully, 
 
6

Case 4:25-cv-01824-JST     Document 99     Filed 08/26/25     Page 2 of 5
 
1  Pursuant to Civil Local Rules 6-2 and 7-12, the Plaintiffs and Federal Defendants stipulate to 
2  and request a stay of the remainder of proceedings in the District Court pending appeal of the 
3  preliminary injunction:  
4  WHEREAS on June 9, 2025, the Court granted in part and denied in part the Plaintiffs’ 
5  Motion for a Preliminary Injunction (ECF No. 81) and the Preliminary Injunction Order was filed 
6  on June 13, 2025 (ECF No. 87); and 
7  WHEREAS the parties file a Joint Status Report RE Compliance on July 2, 2025 (ECF No. 
8  92) demonstrating substantial good faith compliance with the Preliminary Injunction Order; and 
9  WHEREAS Federal Defendants appealed the Preliminary Injunction Order on August 17, 
10  2025 (ECF No. 95); and 
11  WHEREAS upon filing the Notice of Appeal, the district court retains jurisdiction to act on 
12  matters  not  involved  in  the  appeal  unless  an  order  is  entered  staying  the  remainder  of the 
13  proceedings; and  
14  WHEREAS the parties believe the appeal of the Preliminary Injunction Order will result in 
15  appellate guidance that will allow the parties to more efficiently tailor their discovery plan and 
16  could narrow the remaining issues before the District Court;  
17   
18  NOW, THEREFORE, the Parties stipulate as agree follows, subject to leave of Court: 
19  Any further proceedings in the District Court shall be stayed and any pending deadlines 
20  vacated until resolution of the appeal so long as the preliminary injunction remains in force and 
21  effect. 
22   
23  THE PARTIES SO STIPULATE AND RESPECTFULLY REQUEST that the Court stay 
24  further proceedings in the District Court in accordance with their stipulation.
